abstract: Banks are imposing new charges on their customers to make up for the revenue they expect to lose because of a cap on what they can charge merchants for debit-card transactions.
snippet: Banks are imposing new charges on their customers to make up for the revenue they expect to lose because of a cap on what they can charge merchants for debit-card transactions.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America, the nation’s biggest bank, said on Thursday that it planned to start charging customers a $5 monthly fee when they used their debit cards for purchases. It was just one of several new charges expected to hit consumers as new regulations crimp banks’ profits.

headline.main: Banks to Make Customers Pay Fee for Using Debit Cards
headline.print_headline: Banks to Make Customers Pay Debit Card Fee

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)

byline.original: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ben Protess

abstract: The Clearing House Association warns that requiring layers of bank capital protection would devastate the industry’s returns and have a chilling effect on the economy.
snippet: The Clearing House Association warns that requiring layers of bank capital protection would devastate the industry’s returns and have a chilling effect on the economy.
lead_paragraph: When several big banks faced extinction three years ago, many people wondered how such sophisticated institutions had failed to maintain rainy-day funds.

headline.main: Clearing House Group Assails Bank Capital Rules
